title: Exodus Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Exodus chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Exodus Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Exodus Chapter 9.

questions.question: Who did the LORD instruct Moses to go to in order to demand the release of the Israelites?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:1 states that the LORD said unto Moses, 'Go in unto Pharaoh.'

questions.question: What was the reason given by the LORD for commanding Pharaoh to let the people go?
questions.correctAnswer: That they may serve me
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:1 says, 'Let my people go, that they may serve me.'

questions.question: What would happen to the cattle of Egypt if Pharaoh refused to let the Israelites go?
options: A very grievous murrain would strike them
They would be taken to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A very grievous murrain would strike them
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:3 states there shall be a very grievous murrain upon the cattle of Egypt.

questions.question: What did the LORD say about the cattle of the Israelites during the plague on Egypt's cattle?
options: Nothing would die of the children of Israel's cattle
questions.correctAnswer: Nothing would die of the children of Israel's cattle
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:4 says the LORD shall sever between the cattle of Israel and the cattle of Egypt; nothing of the Israelites' cattle would die.

questions.question: What did Pharaoh's heart do after the cattle died in Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: It was hardened
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:7 states that Pharaoh's heart was hardened and he did not let the people go.

questions.question: What did Moses and Aaron take to Pharaoh as a sign that caused boils to break out?
questions.correctAnswer: Ashes of the furnace
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:8-9 describes taking ashes of the furnace to sprinkle toward heaven causing boils to break forth.

questions.question: True or False: The boils affected only the Egyptians, not the magicians.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:11 states the boils were upon the magicians and all the Egyptians.

questions.question: What did the LORD say He would send upon Pharaoh, his servants, and his people to show His power?
questions.correctAnswer: All His plagues
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:14 says God would send all His plagues upon the heart, servants, and people of Pharaoh.

questions.question: What natural disaster did the LORD warn Pharaoh would come with hail and fire?
questions.correctAnswer: A very grievous hail
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:18 describes the LORD's warning of a very grievous hail upon Egypt.

questions.question: Where in Egypt was there no hail during the plague of hail?
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Goshen
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:26 states only in the land of Goshen was there no hail.

questions.question: After the hail stopped, what did Pharaoh do with his heart?
options: He sinned more and hardened his heart
questions.correctAnswer: He sinned more and hardened his heart
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:34 states Pharaoh sinned yet more and hardened his heart.

questions.question: True or False: The hail destroyed the flax and barley but spared the wheat and rye.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:31-32 notes flax and barley were smitten but wheat and rye were not smitten.

questions.question: What did those who feared the word of the LORD do when the hail was coming?
options: They brought their servants and cattle into the houses
questions.correctAnswer: They brought their servants and cattle into the houses
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:20 says those fearing the LORD made their servants and cattle flee into the houses.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Let my people go, that they may ______ me.'
questions.correctAnswer: serve
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:1 says, 'Let my people go, that they may serve me.'

questions.question: True or False: Moses stretched forth his rod toward heaven and the hail stopped immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:33 shows Moses spread his hands to stop the hail, not the rod itself.

medium.title: Exodus Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Exodus Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God during difficult times. Based on Exodus 9, what biblical truth would you share about God's protection?
options: God distinguishes and protects His people from judgment.
God allows all people to suffer equally to teach humility.
God expects us to handle trials without His intervention.
God's protection depends on our works alone.
questions.correctAnswer: God distinguishes and protects His people from judgment.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:4-6 shows God separating the cattle of Israel from Egypt's cattle, sparing Israel's animals, illustrating His protective care for His people in trials.

questions.question: How does Exodus 9 teach about obedience to God's Word in the context of Pharaoh's refusal?
options: Ignoring God's commands leads to hardening of heart and more suffering.
God's commands are for specific people only, not for all.
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring God's commands leads to hardening of heart and more suffering.
questions.explanation: Verses Exodus 9:7 and 12 show Pharaoh's heart being hardened after refusing to obey God's command through Moses, resulting in increased judgment.

questions.question: A believer is praying for breakthrough but feels God is silent. How does Exodus 9 model the role of prayer and intercession?
options: Prayer is a powerful way to seek God's mercy and intervention.
Prayer is ineffective when God has made a decision.
Prayer should be avoided during punishment.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is a powerful way to seek God's mercy and intervention.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:27-29 shows Pharaoh asking Moses to intercede with God to stop the hail, and Moses praying which results in cessation of the plague, illustrating the power of intercession.

questions.question: How does Exodus 9 encourage humility before God even in positions of power?
options: Pharaoh’s repeated hardening of heart shows the danger of pride opposing God.
Power guarantees God's favor regardless of attitude.
God respects only those with earthly authority.
Humility is irrelevant to God's plans.
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh’s repeated hardening of heart shows the danger of pride opposing God.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:34-35 records Pharaoh hardening his heart again after the hail ceases, demonstrating how pride can blind even powerful leaders to God’s sovereignty.

questions.question: What does Exodus 9 teach about God's sovereignty over creation and daily life?
options: God controls natural elements to accomplish His purposes.
Nature acts independently from God's will.
Humans control weather and events on earth.
God is uninvolved in physical realities.
questions.correctAnswer: God controls natural elements to accomplish His purposes.
questions.explanation: The hail, thunder, and fire in Exodus 9:22-24 demonstrate God's control over nature to fulfill His judgments and reveal His power.

questions.question: How does Exodus 9 illustrate the importance of discerning and heeding God’s warnings?
options: Those who feared the word of the LORD protected their servants and cattle.
Warnings from God can be ignored without consequence.
Only priests must listen to God's warnings.
Warnings are symbolic and not meant to be heeded literally.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who feared the word of the LORD protected their servants and cattle.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:20-21 contrasts those who feared God and took action by bringing servants and cattle indoors with those who did not, showing practical obedience to God’s warnings.

questions.question: A believer is facing temptation to harden their heart when trials come. Based on Exodus 9, what biblical principle would you share?
options: Hardening your heart resists God's purpose and prolongs suffering.
Hardening the heart is a sign of spiritual strength.
Ignoring God’s word leads to blessings.
Trials are unrelated to spiritual attitude.
questions.correctAnswer: Hardening your heart resists God's purpose and prolongs suffering.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:12 and 9:35 show Pharaoh’s hardened heart causing him to reject God's commands and endure more plagues, teaching the danger of resisting God.

questions.question: How does Exodus 9 encourage believers to witness and testify about God's power to others?
options: God's acts are meant to declare His name and power throughout the earth.
God’s power is private and for personal gain only.
Witnessing is unnecessary once God has acted.
God's power is shown only to select individuals.
questions.correctAnswer: God's acts are meant to declare His name and power throughout the earth.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:16 emphasizes God raising Pharaoh up to show His power and declare His name worldwide, encouraging believers to share God's mighty works.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged about stewardship after loss. What lesson from Exodus 9 can encourage faithful stewardship during trials?
options: God’s protection over His people’s possessions is certain when they trust Him.
Loss means God is displeased and stewardship is futile.
Stewardship is only about personal gain.
God does not care about earthly resources.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protection over His people’s possessions is certain when they trust Him.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:4-6 and 9:26 show God protecting the land of Goshen and Israel’s cattle from plagues and hail, illustrating divine care over His people’s resources.

questions.question: How does Exodus 9 teach about integrity and honesty in reporting truth?
options: Pharaoh acknowledged the LORD’s righteousness and his own wickedness.
It is acceptable to deny God's truth for convenience.
Honesty is unnecessary in spiritual matters.
Truth can be altered to avoid consequences.
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh acknowledged the LORD’s righteousness and his own wickedness.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:27-28 records Pharaoh confessing his sin and recognizing God’s justice, demonstrating an honest admission of fault before God.

questions.question: In what way does Exodus 9 emphasize perseverance through trials for believers?
options: God’s judgments reveal His power and purpose, calling for trust and endurance.
Trials indicate God’s absence from believers.
Giving up during trials is acceptable.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgments reveal His power and purpose, calling for trust and endurance.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:14-16 explains the plagues are to show God's unmatched power, encouraging believers to trust in His sovereignty through hardship.

questions.question: A believer feels tempted to ignore God's commands when facing difficulties. What insight from Exodus 9 about obedience can help them?
options: Obedience leads to God's protection, disobedience to further hardship.
Obedience is optional in tough times.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience leads to God's protection, disobedience to further hardship.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:20-21 contrasts those who obeyed God’s warning and were spared from hail damage with those who did not, showing practical benefits of obedience.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 9, Pharaoh’s servants who feared the LORD took action to protect themselves and their animals from the hail.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:20 states those who feared the word of the LORD among Pharaoh's servants brought their servants and cattle inside to avoid the hail.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 9 teaches that God's judgments affect all people equally without distinction.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:4-6 and 9:26 clearly show God distinguishing between the Egyptians and Israelites by protecting Israel’s cattle and the land of Goshen from plagues.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "God hardened Pharaoh's heart so that he _____ to let the Israelites go."
questions.correctAnswer: did not
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:12 and 9:35 state that the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart and he did not let the Israelites go, showing God’s sovereign role in the outcome.

questions.question: What does Exodus 9 teach about the role of God’s power in evangelism and witnessing?
options: God’s mighty acts serve to declare His name and power worldwide.
God’s power is secret and should not be shared.
Evangelism relies solely on human effort.
Witnessing is unnecessary when miracles occur.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mighty acts serve to declare His name and power worldwide.
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:16 highlights that God raised up Pharaoh to show His power and declare His name across the earth, encouraging believers to share God's works.

hard.title: Exodus Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Exodus Chapter 9.

questions.question: What is the significance of the LORD severing between the cattle of Israel and those of Egypt in Exodus 9:4, and how does this reflect the covenant relationship between God and Israel?
options: It demonstrates God's protection over Israel's possessions, highlighting His special covenant with them
It shows that Egyptian cattle were more valuable than Israel's
It indicates a test of Pharaoh's economic power
It reflects a ritual cleansing of Israel's livestock
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God's protection over Israel's possessions, highlighting His special covenant with them
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:4 explains that the LORD will not allow any of Israel's cattle to die, showing God's protective hand distinguishing Israel from Egypt, which reflects the covenant relationship where God guards His people and their assets.

questions.question: In the plague of boils described in Exodus 9:8-11, what is the symbolic significance of Moses using ashes from the furnace?
options: The ashes symbolize impurity and judgment, causing boils on man and beast
The ashes represent purification and healing
The ashes are a common Egyptian remedy
The ashes are a form of Egyptian magic countered by Moses
questions.correctAnswer: The ashes symbolize impurity and judgment, causing boils on man and beast
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:9-10 shows that ashes from the furnace were used by Moses to create boils, symbolizing divine judgment and impurity spreading across Egypt, contrasting with the holiness expected of God’s people.

questions.question: How does Pharaoh’s repeated hardening of his heart (Exodus 9:7, 12, 34-35) function within the narrative's theological framework?
options: It illustrates divine sovereignty and human stubbornness leading to judgment
It shows Pharaoh's repentance and eventual release of Israel
It indicates a gradual softening of Pharaoh’s resistance
It is a literary device to end the narrative abruptly
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates divine sovereignty and human stubbornness leading to judgment
questions.explanation: The repeated hardening of Pharaoh’s heart in Exodus 9 highlights the interplay between divine control and human will, demonstrating God’s sovereign plan unfolding despite human resistance (Exodus 9:12, 34-35).

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the plague of hail being localized in Egypt but sparing the land of Goshen (Exodus 9:26)?
options: It demonstrates God's protection over His people and foreshadows divine deliverance
It shows that Goshen was geographically immune to natural disasters
It indicates that Goshen was less important economically
It reflects an Egyptian ritual to protect Goshen
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God's protection over His people and foreshadows divine deliverance
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:26 describes that only Goshen, where the Israelites lived, was spared the hail, emphasizing God's protective care over His covenant people and foreshadowing their eventual redemption.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 9:24, the hail was accompanied by thunder and fire, a combination not previously seen in Egypt.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:24 states that there was hail and fire mingled together, very grievous, such as had not been seen in Egypt since it became a nation, underscoring the uniqueness and severity of this plague.

questions.question: In Exodus 9:14-16, God's declaration to Pharaoh about sending plagues upon his heart serves what literary and theological purpose?
options: To reveal God's unmatched power and declare His name throughout the earth
To show that Pharaoh is a righteous king
To indicate a temporary punishment with no lasting effect
To suggest that Egypt will become the new chosen nation
questions.correctAnswer: To reveal God's unmatched power and declare His name throughout the earth
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:16 explicitly states that God raised Pharaoh up to show His power and make His name known worldwide, emphasizing God's sovereignty and the purpose behind the plagues.

questions.question: Which agricultural crops are specifically mentioned in Exodus 9:31-32 as being affected or unaffected by the hail, and what might this indicate about the timing of the plague?
options: Barley and flax were smitten; wheat and rye were not yet grown up
Wheat and rye were smitten; barley and flax were unaffected
questions.correctAnswer: Barley and flax were smitten; wheat and rye were not yet grown up
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:31-32 distinguishes between barley and flax being damaged, while wheat and rye were still immature, indicating a specific agricultural season and precise timing of the plague.

questions.question: What does the instruction for Moses to sprinkle ashes toward heaven (Exodus 9:8-10) reveal about ancient Near Eastern ritual and symbolic acts?
options: It acts as a divine sign invoking judgment and cosmic authority
It is a purely medical treatment for boils
It is an Egyptian magical practice adopted by Moses
It represents a gesture of worship to Egyptian gods
questions.correctAnswer: It acts as a divine sign invoking judgment and cosmic authority
questions.explanation: Sprinkling ashes toward heaven symbolizes God's judgment spreading over Egypt, aligning with ancient Near Eastern practices where ritual acts represented divine power and authority (Exodus 9:8-10).

questions.question: Exodus 9:20-21 contrasts the reactions of Pharaoh’s servants to the coming hailstorm. What does this contrast reveal about knowledge and fear of God in the narrative?
options: Those who feared the LORD obeyed and protected their servants and cattle
All servants ignored the warning and suffered equally
Pharaoh’s servants were indifferent to the plague
Only Egyptian priests feared the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Those who feared the LORD obeyed and protected their servants and cattle
questions.explanation: Verses 20-21 show that servants who respected God's warning took action to protect themselves and their animals, illustrating the theme of reverence for God leading to preservation.

questions.question: How does the narrative of Exodus 9 demonstrate typology, particularly in the relationship between Moses and the plagues?
options: Moses acts as a mediator and prophet, foreshadowing later intercessory roles in Scripture
Moses is depicted as a warrior king defeating Pharaoh
Moses represents an Egyptian deity conflicting with the LORD
Moses is a passive observer of events
questions.correctAnswer: Moses acts as a mediator and prophet, foreshadowing later intercessory roles in Scripture
questions.explanation: Moses’ role in commanding and interceding during the plagues (e.g., Exodus 9:29-33) typifies the prophetic mediator role fulfilled by leaders throughout biblical history.

questions.question: Why does Pharaoh’s acknowledgment of sin in Exodus 9:27-28 fail to result in lasting repentance and release of the Israelites?
options: Because his heart was hardened again, showing human resistance to God’s will
Because the Egyptian priests opposed him
Because the Israelites refused to leave
questions.correctAnswer: Because his heart was hardened again, showing human resistance to God’s will
questions.explanation: Despite Pharaoh admitting sin (Exodus 9:27), subsequent verses (9:34-35) reveal his heart hardened again, indicating persistent rebellion against God.

questions.question: The phrase 'Let my people go, that they may serve me' appears multiple times in Exodus 9. What does this repeated demand emphasize in the context of ancient Israelite identity?
options: The centrality of covenantal worship and exclusive service to God
The desire for political independence from Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The centrality of covenantal worship and exclusive service to God
questions.explanation: The repeated phrase (e.g., Exodus 9:1, 13) stresses Israel’s purpose to serve Yahweh alone, highlighting their identity as God’s covenant people.

questions.question: How does the plague of hail in Exodus 9 align with the motif of divine control over nature found elsewhere in the Hebrew Bible?
options: It demonstrates God’s power over natural elements, reinforcing His sovereignty
It is a natural weather event mistakenly attributed to God
It is a sign of Egyptian gods’ displeasure
It shows nature’s independence from divine control
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God’s power over natural elements, reinforcing His sovereignty
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:23-25 describes God controlling hail, thunder, and fire, consistent with biblical themes of God's dominion over creation (e.g., Psalm 29).

questions.question: What is the significance of the magicians being unable to stand before Moses because of the boils (Exodus 9:11) in the broader contest between Yahweh and Egyptian gods?
options: It symbolizes Yahweh’s superiority over Egyptian magicians and deities
It indicates that magicians were immune to the plague
It suggests magicians controlled the plague
It shows Moses learning Egyptian magic
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Yahweh’s superiority over Egyptian magicians and deities
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:11 reveals that even Egyptian magicians suffered from the boils, demonstrating the impotence of Egypt’s gods and magicians compared to Yahweh.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 9:35, the heart of Pharaoh was finally softened, leading to the release of the children of Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:35 states that Pharaoh’s heart remained hardened and he would not let the Israelites go, despite the plagues.

theological.title: Exodus Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Exodus Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose God commands Moses to demand Pharaoh to let Israel go?
options: That they may serve the LORD
That they may conquer other nations
That they may build a temple
questions.correctAnswer: That they may serve the LORD
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:1 states God’s purpose for Israel's release is so that they may serve Him. This aligns with Deuteronomy 6:13 and Joshua 24:15 emphasizing serving God alone, and Matthew 4:10 where Jesus affirms worship and service to God.

questions.question: What plague did the LORD bring upon the cattle of Egypt in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: A grievous murrain (disease)
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:3-6 records a grievous murrain upon the Egyptian cattle, but not upon Israel's. This demonstrates God's protective justice, similar to the Passover lamb’s blood sparing Israel (Exodus 12:23), and foreshadows Christ as protector (John 10:11).

questions.question: How did God demonstrate His distinction between Israel’s cattle and Egypt’s?
options: No cattle of Israel died, but all of Egypt’s did
Israel’s cattle were moved to another land
questions.correctAnswer: No cattle of Israel died, but all of Egypt’s did
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:4-6 states God would sever between Israel’s cattle and Egypt’s, showing divine protection over His covenant people, as also seen in Psalm 91:7-8 and Hebrews 11:33.

questions.question: What did God instruct Moses and Aaron to use to cause boils upon the Egyptians?
questions.correctAnswer: Ashes of the furnace
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:8-10 shows God commanded ashes to be sprinkled to cause boils, demonstrating His sovereign control over nature and judgment. This mirrors divine judgment imagery in Job 2:7 and Revelation 16:2.

questions.question: What was the reaction of Pharaoh’s magicians to the boils?
options: They could not stand before Moses because they were afflicted
questions.correctAnswer: They could not stand before Moses because they were afflicted
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:11 indicates the magicians themselves suffered boils and could not oppose Moses, illustrating the impotence of false powers against God’s judgment, consistent with Isaiah 41:29 and 2 Corinthians 12:7.

questions.question: Despite the plagues, what consistent condition of Pharaoh’s heart is repeatedly mentioned?
questions.correctAnswer: It was hardened
questions.explanation: The hardening of Pharaoh’s heart (Exodus 9:7, 12, 34-35) reveals God’s sovereignty in judgment and human resistance to repentance, paralleling Romans 9:17-18 and John 12:40.

questions.question: What plague did God threaten that involved hail and fire mingled with hail?
questions.correctAnswer: A grievous hailstorm with fire
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:18-24 describes a devastating hailstorm mingled with fire, unprecedented in Egypt, showing God’s power over creation, similar to the fire and hail in Job 38:22-23 and Revelation 8:7.

questions.question: Where was the hailstorm notably absent during this plague?
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Goshen
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:26 states hail did not fall on Goshen, where Israel lived, indicating God’s protection over His covenant people, echoing the Passover protection (Exodus 12:23) and God’s preservation in Psalm 91.

questions.question: How did Pharaoh respond after the hailstorm plague?
options: He admitted his sin and asked Moses to pray
He refused to speak to Moses
questions.correctAnswer: He admitted his sin and asked Moses to pray
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:27-28 records Pharaoh confessing his sin and requesting Moses to intercede, showing a momentary recognition of God’s righteousness, paralleling Jonah 3:9 and 1 John 1:9 on repentance.

questions.question: What did Moses say he would do after leaving Pharaoh to stop the hail?
options: Spread his hands to the LORD
Call on the Israelites to pray
questions.correctAnswer: Spread his hands to the LORD
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:29-30 reveals Moses’ role as mediator, raising hands to God to cease the hail, prefiguring intercessory prayer seen in Numbers 11:2 and 1 Timothy 2:1.

questions.question: Which crops were smitten by the hailstorm according to Exodus 9?
questions.correctAnswer: Flax and barley
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:31 states flax and barley were damaged, while wheat and rye were unharmed, illustrating selective judgment and God’s control over natural timing, as in Genesis 1:11 and Joel 2:22.

questions.question: What does Exodus 9:14 teach about God’s purpose in sending plagues upon Pharaoh and Egypt?
options: To show there is none like God in all the earth
To punish Israel for their sins
questions.correctAnswer: To show there is none like God in all the earth
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:14 reveals God’s intent to demonstrate His unrivaled sovereignty, consistent with Isaiah 45:5 and Psalm 86:8, affirming monotheism and divine supremacy.

questions.question: According to Exodus 9:15-16, why did God raise up Pharaoh?
options: To display His power and declare His name throughout the earth
questions.correctAnswer: To display His power and declare His name throughout the earth
questions.explanation: Exodus 9:16 explains Pharaoh’s role as an instrument to reveal God’s glory, echoing Romans 9:17-18 and Isaiah 43:7 about God’s sovereign purposes.

questions.question: How does this chapter illustrate the doctrine of divine justice?
options: By punishing Egypt but sparing Israel
questions.correctAnswer: By punishing Egypt but sparing Israel
questions.explanation: Exodus 9 shows God’s righteous judgment against Egypt’s sin while protecting Israel, consistent with Psalm 7:11, Romans 2:5-6, and Revelation 15:3 on God as a just judge.

questions.question: What theological theme is shown by Pharaoh’s repeated hardening of heart despite the plagues?
options: Human resistance to God’s will and divine sovereignty in judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Human resistance to God’s will and divine sovereignty in judgment
questions.explanation: Pharaoh’s hardened heart (Exodus 9:7, 12, 34-35) reveals the tension between human stubbornness and God’s sovereign plan, a theme also found in Romans 9:18-21 and John 12:39-40.

questions.question: What role does Moses play in this chapter in relation to God and Pharaoh?
options: Mediator and prophet proclaiming God’s commands and interceding
questions.correctAnswer: Mediator and prophet proclaiming God’s commands and interceding
questions.explanation: Moses acts as mediator and prophet (Exodus 9:1, 13, 29), delivering God’s words and praying for relief, consistent with his role in Deuteronomy 34:10 and Hebrews 3:1.
